choices.A: Configuration changes have been installed on FortiGate, which means the FortiGate configuration has been changed.
choices.C: Configuration changes directly made on FortiGate have been automatically updated to the device-level database.
choices.B: The latest revision history for the managed FortiGate does match the FortiGate running configuration.
choices.D: The latest revision history for the managed FortiGate does not match the device-level database.

discussion.content:
Correct answers are B & D:

FortiManager 7.2 Study Guide page 160

"conf: in sync" means FortiGate configuration is in sync with the latest running revision history.

"db: modified" and "cond: pending" means that changes have been made to the device-level settings and need to be installed.

Selected Answer: BD
The example on this slide shows that the FortiGate configuration is in sync with the latest running revision history. However, changes have been made to the device-level settings. That is why the CLI output is showing db:modified and the cond is showing as pending. After you install the changes on FortiGate, it will show db: not modified and cond:OK.

db:modified = Config changes made on FMG
cond:in sync = Latest revision history in sync with FGT running-config
cond:pending = Config changes needed to be installed

Reference [Page 160] - https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortimanager-study-guide-for-fortimanager-72.html

Selected Answer: BD
B. The output indicates "STATUS: dev-0: modified," suggesting that there have been modifications to the FortiGate configuration. This implies that the latest revision history for the managed FortiGate does match the FortiGate running configuration.

D. The output includes information about the status and synchronization, and it mentions "cont: 0 sync: second: pending: dr: received: com:." This suggests that there might be differences or pending changes between the FortiGate and the device-level database, indicating that the latest revision history for the managed FortiGate does not match the device-level database.

choices.A: You must create an MEA special policy on FortiManager using the super user profile.
choices.D: The administrator must have the super user profile.
choices.C: When you configure MEA, you must open TCP or UDP port 540.
choices.B: You must open the ports to the Fortinet registry.

questions.question_text: Which two settings are required for FortiManager Management Extension Applications (MEA)? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
B. FMG uses TCP 443 to connect to the fortinet registry, and isnt tcp 443 enabled in fmg by default? Eliminating B as the correct answer? Isnt A and D the correct answer here?

Selected Answer: BD
B: FortiManager uses port TCP port 443 or TCP port 4443 to connect to the Fortinet registry and download 
MEAs. Make sure that the port is also open on any upstream FortiGate devices.

D: FMG administrator with super user profile can enable MEAs

Reference [Page 270] - https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortimanager-study-guide-for-fortimanager-72.html

comments.content: thank you for sharing details and link

choices.B: Ungraceful closed sessions will keep the ADOM in a locked state until the administrator session times out.
choices.D: Unlocking an ADOM will install configuration changes automatically on managed devices.
choices.C: The same administrator can lock more than one ADOM at the same time.
choices.A: Unlocking an ADOM will submit configuration changes automatically to the approval administrator.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
A. Wrong. That'd be Workflow mode
B. Correct
C. Correct. 
D. Wrong. Changes need to be manually pushed to the managed device.

Selected Answer: BC
BC are correct answers

Selected Answer: BC
B: The policy lock is automatically released at administrator timeout, or if the administrator closes a session 
gracefully without unlocking the policy package or policy. 

Reference [Page 240] - https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortimanager-study-guide-for-fortimanager-72.html
